awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Interface Engineered Amorphous Alloys for Thermoplastic Forming of Ductile Bulk Metallic Glasses
awd_abstract_narration:
Metallic glasses have evolved into a new class of high-strength engineering materials with compelling benefits for the aerospace, electronics, and automotive industries. However, their technological utility has been hindered by a propensity for localized failure in tension and limited processing routes for bulk production. This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award supports research to engineer amorphous alloys structures with enhanced ductility and formability for the production of bulk metallic glass sheets. Deformation behavior and its dependence on microstructural variables will be elucidated through synergistic computational and experimental research activities. For the first time, interface engineered bulk metallic glass sheets will be synthesized through additive spray manufacturing, which will provide a myriad of new opportunities for the design and production of metallic glass components through thermoplastic forming. Research activities are integrated into new educational initiatives that advance the engagement of underrepresented students in minority participation programs, provide curriculum enrichment for engineering majors, and facilitate the establishment of a sustainable mechanism for interfacing with regional high schools.  

This CAREER award supports fundamental research to understand the mechanisms underpinning strain delocalization in interface engineered amorphous alloys containing intergranular regions of excess free volume. The guiding hypothesis is shear localization in metallic glasses can be interrupted by regions of excess free volume that promote the distributed nucleation of many subcritical shear bands, thus producing a more homogenous plastic response via elimination of a dominant shear front.  The research team will perform molecular dynamics simulations of shear localization collectively with advanced characterization and nanomechanical testing of interface engineered amorphous alloys to elucidate the role of interfacial structure and amorphous grain size in the mechanics of strain delocalization. Innovations in additive spray manufacturing will be devised to enable transformational microstructures that effectively delocalize the accumulation of plastic strain via distributed microplasticity. A chief societal impact of this research is the ability to produce ductile amorphous alloy sheets via additive spray manufacturing that can be used to revolutionize the sheet metal industry as well as produce bulk metallic glass components through net-shape thermoplastic forming processes.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Metallic glasses have become widely accepted as a technologically important class of materials owing to their extraordinary strength and intriguing deformation physics.  While their ductility is often limited by plastic flow localizing into shear bands, introducing structural heterogeneities into an amorphous alloy promotes a more homogenous plastic response. The primary goal of this CAREER award was to develop an understanding of the mechanisms underpinning the deformation behavior of metallic glasses containing structural heterogeneities including regions of varying free volume and engineered crystalline inclusions.  Research activities were guided by the hypothesis that shear localization can be interrupted by these structural heterogeneities promoting the distributed nucleation of many subcritical shear bands, which promotes a more homogenous plastic response through the elimination of a dominant shear front.  Atomistic nanoglass models were constructed through hydrostatic compression of amorphous nanoparticles.  By distinguishing local regions of excess free volume, the simulated nanoglasses revealed that structural motifs within amorphous interfaces can be tuned through control over the effective sintering temperature. Intrinsic size effects in nanoglass plasticity were shown to be independent of the amorphous grain size and instead dependent on the excess free volume and degree of short-range ordering in the interfaces.  Partitioning of plastic strain to the more disordered interfacial regions inhibited the formation of a primary shear band, which ultimately governed strain delocalization and homogenous flow. Flow delocalization was also quantified in metallic glasses containing crystalline inclusions.  The presence of amorphous-crystalline interfaces reduced the activation barrier for shear banding while the crystalline phase effectively arrested propagating shear fonts to enhance the shear band nucleation rate, in turn promoting a more homogenous plastic response. An accompanying crossover from the shear plane to maximum shear stress yield criterion was uncovered at a crystalline fraction of approximately 60%, thus signaling an effective transition from incipient to homogeneous flow due to crystalline plasticity dominating strain accumulation in the composite microstructure. Innovations in additive spray manufacturing were devised that enabled interface microstructures to be realized in iron-based amorphous alloys with two processing routes explored and total scattering techniques employed to quantify the short-to-medium range atomic disorder and its evolution through annealing below the crystallization point. By comparing short-ranging ordering trends with the nanoglass atomistic models, evolution of the disorder upon annealing was shown to be consistent with interfacial thickening accommodated by local free volume reduction via diffusion from the amorphous interfaces into adjacent particle cores.  Research activities have been integrated into university educational initiatives that: (i) advance the engagement of underrepresented students in engineering through collaboration with the Center for Inclusive Education, (ii) promote curriculum enrichment for engineering majors and the establishment of a new materials engineering major, and (iii) provide experiential learning opportunities for the Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) Program through the integration of materials science modules into the Introduction to Engineering course for educators and professionals.


Last Modified: 03/30/2023
Modified by: Jason Trelewicz

    B. Cheng, J.R. Trelewicz

    Interfacial Plasticity Governs Strain Delocalization in Metallic Nanoglasses
  • Amorphous-crystalline interfaces in metallic glass composites reduce the barrier for shear banding while the crystalline phase arrests propagating shear fonts to enhance the shear band nucleation rate, which promotes a more homogenous plastic response above a crystalline phase fraction of 60%.
    J.M. Gentile, J.R. Trelewicz
    Copyrighted
    Jason Trelewicz
    Microstructural Dependence of the Incipient to Homogeneous Flow Transition in Metallic Glass Composites
  • Innovations in additive spray manufacturing enable interface microstructures in iron-based amorphous alloys with total scattering techniques revealing short-range disorder that evolves through annealing, which is attributed to an interfacial thickening effect from nanoglass simulations
    J.M. Gentile, D.J. Sprouster, B. Cheng, J.R. Trelewicz
    Copyrighted
    Jason Trelewicz
    Interfacial Free Volume Redistribution in Amorphous Interfaces During Relaxation of a Spray Deposited Amorphous Alloy
por.por_txt_cntn:
Metallic glasses have become widely accepted as a technologically important class of materials owing to their extraordinary strength and intriguing deformation physics.  While their ductility is often limited by plastic flow localizing into shear bands, introducing structural heterogeneities into an amorphous alloy promotes a more homogenous plastic response. The primary goal of this CAREER award was to develop an understanding of the mechanisms underpinning the deformation behavior of metallic glasses containing structural heterogeneities including regions of varying free volume and engineered crystalline inclusions.  Research activities were guided by the hypothesis that shear localization can be interrupted by these structural heterogeneities promoting the distributed nucleation of many subcritical shear bands, which promotes a more homogenous plastic response through the elimination of a dominant shear front.  Atomistic nanoglass models were constructed through hydrostatic compression of amorphous nanoparticles. Innovations in additive spray manufacturing were devised that enabled interface microstructures to be realized in iron-based amorphous alloys with two processing routes explored and total scattering techniques employed to quantify the short-to-medium range atomic disorder and its evolution through annealing below the crystallization point. By comparing short-ranging ordering trends with the nanoglass atomistic models, evolution of the disorder upon annealing was shown to be consistent with interfacial thickening accommodated by local free volume reduction via diffusion from the amorphous interfaces into adjacent particle cores.
